reviewText:
A person with no recollection of his or her past boards a train that never seems to end.
A shadow by the name of Little Mary tells this person that they are on the train of afterlife.  At the twelfth hour, the ride will end.  Where it ends up depends entirely on the person.

I really loved the story, and the amount of enjoyment I felt after the whole story clicked in place is beyond the scope of my literary abilities to explain.

Even then a few things are left open, but I liked that. The slow pacing of the story works pretty well with the slightly cryptic storytelling.

reviewText: This game takes a perspective of the afterlife. The train stands as a common ground of a setting where you have windows and other passengers. Each one having their own existence shadowed. In this game, you are caught between decisions and if you like fortunes (Tarot Cards specifically) or have an interest in them; making a psychological aspect of who or what you are. The story resolves around hours and you are drawn to specific cards, these cards you choose also grant you the cards in Steam for players unless you idle and lose the choice of chance then. You have to get through those points. The cards all have an interesting connection of past. The more you go through you find a way to identify the people around you as well as yourself. For instance, these people/shadows leave and move around. DIfferent choices lead to different status and depending on them, the choice shows a significant effect on dialogue. If you are to think of VNs and routes this has a very basic but understandable concept. However the text shows deep insight into the creation or memory recall" of yourself or another. Basically you got to play it a bit to understand what it gets at. Summarizing it so far it's one of those games that it's a choice that can matter. As stated you can only choose 9 cards but events and discussions show up that will make you go along the story. However as for anymore to spoil
date: the game shows it's bits of mystery and suspense. For those seeking a good read and play evaluation
recommended:
try this. However if price is not for you wait. It doesn't have to be rushed this game is a patience on time and sadly there is no Screen shot button as well as an auto play. So you'll be clicking quite a  lot. Enjoy it if you do. The game makes you view death in a certain way as well as questions of life. Throughout the game on each end you get the password. I will not spoil it for you however there are some online guides. Although there is an extras gallery it cannot be unlocked without a code. Alas this game trult did play quite a bunch of high replayable moments. If you take the time to decipher and figure out all the characters and names in the story while playing the routes. You will find a deeper appreciation.
Tips and Hint: Check your stats and decisions. Save before them to understand and save yourself the trouble. Although some choices just change a few things specifically. Your stats make a difference to the ending. Also there are passwords in the main menu continue screen and endings can be replayed there. *I HIGHLY RECOMMEND FOR THE IN-DEPTH VN route takers you take the time to read.









-SPOILERS-
There are two protaganist routes(Wind and Wing
hoursPlayed: you start as Wind)! As well as a side story.\nWatch the Opening if you want to figure out the true end "phase". If you are looking for passwords. I will include a guide later. However they will just spoil it for you."

reviewText: I was pleasantly surprised by this title. Albeit the game was short but the story was compelling. It took me roughly 5 hours to complete it in its entirety. You're on a train with several people who have all recently died and you're basically piecing together your past. This game deals with some serious issues, such as suicide, death and a few other mature subjects. Most of which are approached subtly as you progress through the story uncovering your past but also through interacting with the other passengers on the train. The haunting melody of the soundtrack with the¬†muted color scheme adds to the overall atmosphere of the game. Not to mention that the characters you're talking to for the most part are silhouettes of their former self.\n\nThere are many choices that affect the endings you get and you'll need to finish the game a number of times before the true
recommended: and you uncover the complete story. Of course you could cheat and just look up the passwords to unlock them instead of playing the game through a few times but I feel like each ending lends itself to a bit more of the main character's personality and state of mind. You also get to understand how the other characters relate to them. This is a really good game and I fully¬†enjoyed it."

reviewText:
NOTE:  This review has been updated since its initial posting

************************

The concept for this visual novel is pretty good - you're dead, and everyone else on the train is dead as well.  You talk to the other passengers, as you try to figure out the mystery of what your life was, before your train reaches its destination.  We could've had some really interesting characters here, but the dev made the story so vague, and all the supporting characters too, that the entire game is just boring because of all the ambiguity.

The ONLY remotely interesting thing about this game initially is the endings, and it's a total chore to get all 4 of the initial endings"
date: because you can't skip ANYTHING even though 90% of the game is the exact same no matter what your choices are.\n\nEventually
recommended: if you unlock all 4 initial endings
hoursPlayed: you get access to the REAL game
voteText:
called Wing's Path.  This is where you actually have a decent shot at piecing together what your character's life was like.  Wing's Path prevents me from recommending this game for two reasons:

1)  You are expected to complete all 4 initial endings before getting access to the real game.  Really... I'm expected to waste 4 playthroughs of my real life time?  That's dopey.  It should unlock after 2 endings.

2)  The fact that the real game is called "Wing's Path" is troubling.  It's actually an appropriate name
helpfulPercent: but it's related to a lie told in the game that almost all players will accept as a given fact of the story
votesHelpful: and this red herring makes piecing together the story by yourself VERY difficult on your first few playthroughs.  If this in-game lie was not told
votesTotal: the player would have a much easier time piecing together the story throughout their playthroughs of the game.\n\nAlso
votesFunny: there are two characters with the name "Wing" in this game - one major character
commentsCount: and one minor character.  This again unnecessarily complicates the player's ability to piece together the past
column16: and I can't think of a reason why the dev chose to make two completely different characters have the same name
column17: other than to confuse you.\n\nUnlocking the true ending of the game (which thankfully gives an entire explanation of your life)
column18: is pretty much impossible on your own.  Fortunately
column19:
the dev has a guide to assist you in your pursuit of the true ending:

http://www.zeiva.net/other/toa/guide_ending.html

If you choose to buy this game though
column20: I would recommend getting 2 initial endings on your own
column21: using the guide to get the other 2 initial endings
column22: getting 1 Wing's Path ending on your own
column23: and then guiding for the rest.\n\nThe dev mentions in his comment of this review that you can hold down the down arrow key to skip through a lot of text.  It's very useful on ending farming
column24: but I don't think it's mentioned in game.\n\nAll in all
column25: the unnecessarily long "walling off" of the true game
column27: and name confusion prevent me from recommending it.  The story fragments given
column28: and the lack of any timeline for the fragments
column29: already made the story difficult to put together as is.  There was no reason to make things even harder with an in-game lie
column30: and two distinctly separate characters with the same name. I'm not going to say "don't play it"
column31: but I'm not going to say "you should play it" either.  Get it on sale for a few bucks if the positive reviews really pique your interest

reviewText:
I really enjoyed this story... the feels... lots of decisions and right/wrong choices. Music, art, good too!

BUT...

There's no save feature. Which means you have to play the entire game through at least 9 times to get all the endings. I like it, but theres really no need for that.

In its current state there's just no way I could recommend it. You can actually save the game, but when it ends the game wipes all the saves. Plz add a REAL save feature and then I can recommend this.

The developer has fixed the save bug and that was the biggest problem with the game. Now you can just mess around and try out different dialogue easier without worrying about having to replay the whole thing if you screw up.

I'd still recommend following a guide to get all good endings, its very tricky.

reviewText: The first thing I noticed about this game is that the artwork is really good. It's absolutely a joy to look at. First play through went quickly. I did all the choices and ended up in hell after about a half hour. Then I tried it again and did a few things differently, and the game lasted twice the time and I unlocked a different ending. Still trying to unlock a few more. I really like the feel of the game, the story, obviously the art, and the music. It's quite a step above most of the visual novels on steam, and well worth your time. I got this game in a bundle so I didn't pay full price, so I'd recommend waiting for a good sale or for it to be bundled again if you're looking for a deal, otherwise I'd say give it a go at full price, considering it's also not nearly as over-priced as some of the steam visual novels.\n9/10 so far. Might change that after unlocking more endings.

reviewText:
It's interesting to play a visual novel, where most of the characters you see have to be imagined, as they're not more than silhouettes of what they could be. But I do wonder, how they can talk, without being able to make out their genders through their voices. Unless they see the text, too!
And then I wonder, if they forget everything from their former life, but still are clearly able to think rationally, just like humans, wouldn't they also be affected by mental disorders, just like humans?

I as someone who hasn't played terribly many VNs, but has seen a lot of anime, can say that I enjoyed it a fair bit.
The fact that it's not based on the cuteness of the characters is what has drawn me into it. There were also a few moments that gave me the shivers, in a good way.

reviewText:
Train of Afterlife is a very thought provoking VN that explores one of the possibilities of what the afterlife could be like through the form of playing as someone that has lost their memories and finds themselves on a train leading to destinations unknown. Along the way you meet other passengers that are also going on their own journeys of discovery trying to figure out their past lives and who they once were. Even though the entire game takes place within the setting of the train it didn't take away from my enjoyment of the game and I replayed it quite a few times.

This is my second time playing a VN from this developer and once again they have created an amazing atmospheric  setting that creates the perfect mix of the unknown and curiosity as you try to figure out who you really are, why you can't remember your past and the reasons why you are on the train to start with.

I can definitely recommend this to anyone who wants a good story that has wonderful art, music and by the end of it makes you sit back and really think.

reviewText:
Train of afterlife is a game which is all about the atmosphere. To appreciate that Visual Novel, you must like that essential part lingering during the entire game. All is thought for that aspect with the low pace and the musics.

The story is a little masterpiece, as it plunges the reader little by little in the understanding in the form of a kind of puzzle which unknots itself in the very end. The atmosphere and the story together give form to a very emotionnal grand finale which might make you cry because of its intensity.

There are quite a lot of choices in the game and they are really important to move forward in the story and through the different endings. Some people will say that the game needs a guide, but I don't agree. Anybody passionnated by the story and the atmosphere will try to find all fine details and a clear logic will eventually reveal itself to make the good choices. However, there is a very difficult riddle at the end of the game, impossible for me to resolve without the clue in the author's site (but really, it worths the effort).

The Visual Novel talks about sensitive subjects, but I don't think that could be a problem for anyone. Now, the only flaw for me is the repetitiveness. There are 9 endings, and you will start again and again the game to get all of them. Well, if you are passionnated by the atmosphere and the story, it's not a big deal but I can understand some people give up because of that (even if I recommend against doing that because the very end is really excellent).

Once again I'm impressed by a Zeiva's Visual Novel. For me that work is almost perfect, and that's rare from me but I put a 9/10 for this one, it's a masterpiece.

reviewText:
I'll admit I like to play visual novels, and I'm always hyped because the characters look neat in one, or I like this other one's style. But if there's no actual interaction, I just can't stay engaged. I hate to admit it, but I've passed up some wonderful VNs because they're.. basically a movie. I'm not a movie person; I get antsy, and outright bored. This VN, though.. Has a ton of interaction. Constantly keeping me engaged, thinking about what's going on.

I love it.

Train of Afterlife starts you off as somebody who has passed away, and no longer has memories of their living moments. You board a train, and meet very real characters throughout the course of it. Real, in the sense, that they're relatable. You feel like you could actually meet these people; they're wonderfully-written.

This game had some of the most profound, thought-provoking things to say, sometimes seemingly out of nowhere. The entire atmosphere of the train can be wonderfully calming, or uncomfortably eerie, and it all depends on you, the player. Not the choices you make as the character, but how you actually interpret it. Things may seem one way or another, and it's all based on your perspective.

With nine endings in total to go through, I'm going to say this: It's not going to make sense after your first playthrough. You will be utterly confused, curious. With plenty of forking paths in conversations, you won't see every possible conversation outcome in one game.

If you're big on the game looking nice art-wise, just take a look through the store's screenshots. You've got nothing to lose. I, personally, am a big fan of it. It matches the game's style of being peaceful or creepy; however you'd like to view it. The music, in general, is very pretty. It fits the scenes well, and more than once I found myself sitting in one area and listening to the track over and over.

Tl;dr This game is beautifully written, engaging, and utterly profound in its own sense. The art is appealing, the music is nice, and it's got tons of replay value. I'd suggest to not look up screenshots outside of the store page, just so you don't spoil anything for yourself if you plan on playing it.

reviewText:
Train of Afterlife is a short, somber visual novel that deals with its dark subject matter in a fairly levelheaded and realistic manner. It's also one of those kinds of stories where you can piece together its mysteries before they're revealed ‚Äî and you kind of have to for its excellent final puzzle ‚Äî which I quite enjoyed being able to do. The characters and their dialogue all feel as fleshed-out as they could be for the game's length, though it may take multiple playthroughs to realize that since initially they feel somewhat stilted and their full story can only be revealed through taking certain actions at the right times. Perhaps my only criticisms of the plot are that several of the endings feel pointless, and that the relationship between the main characters veers too close to anime garbage territory, but even then I can't say I found it completely unbelievable considering the circumstances.

Gameplay is typical; you read messages, move around the train, and every now and then make a decision that impacts what ending you'll end up getting. Unlike most visual novels, there (usually) isn't an option to skip already-read text, but at the very least clicking rapidly does the same job. On the other hand, the fades from scene to scene are a bit slow, which can be irritating when trying to quickly repeat actions to see another ending.

Graphically, there's not too much to say since the game takes enough of a minimalist approach that you can see most of the game's graphics in the screenshots on the store page. For what it's worth, I do think the background art is rendered nicely and the subdued colors perfectly set the mood. There are only a few tracks of music in the game, all of which are from royalty-free websites, but the selection is fitting and soothing.

After clearing all 9 endings of the game there's also a brief side-story to read through, which at the end pushed plausibility a bit too much for me to appreciate everything else about it, and an extras gallery, which, in addition to including a CG viewer and a music player, also has character bios and such where the writer also speaks about her inspirations, which I found interesting to read.

Overall, though I wasn't blown away by its conclusion, nor moved to tears by its events, Train of Afterlife executed its premise with enough finesse to captivate me for the few hours its journey lasted.

reviewText: I was completely interested in this game once I read the description, and I knew I had to play it. It's was definitely worth the time and effort to play it, and it plays very differently than most Visual Novels. While majority deal with school life, girls and such, this one takes a more DARKER tone, and you experience the story through a very thought out storyline. Although the image arts are a bit bland and unappealing to most, I find they do their part in helping the story, and are very basic too. The game deals with heavy metal subjects and things most people wouldn't like talking or playing about, but I'd highly recommend playing it and trying it out! It's got such great content for such a short game!

reviewText: This is a slow-paced VN. Get ready for lots of repeating scenes, and generous use of the mouse button since it doesn't support keyboards like modern VNs. A lack of a skip function, save for select areas, makes this more tedious than it needs to be. Fortunately, it's improved upon earlier versions with the inclusion of a save function, which is extremely useful.\n\nThe story makes this one, instead of the music (which fits well, but only serves as a supporting character) or the art (simple and muted, but it fits with the theme). The story quietly revised how I understood its subject matter, without throwing it in my face or leaving most things unexplained, as is the case with some other VNs of this genre. It made me pensive, contemplative, happy, and calm. I couldn't ask for more.

reviewText:
The set-up is intriguing and mysterious, it's plot deeper than it seems. It tends towards the more philosophical and pyschological side which makes this VN quite a good read. It gives interesting perspective to life in general as well.

One thing to note though is that the characters are all represented by shadows throughout most of the 12 hours. Their appearance will only be fully shown when you unlock their story/past.

Pros:
- Many endings (9 in total - and each ending is unique)
- The puns of the names Zeiva chose for each character [Zeiva does explain it in-game]
- The one-liners after each ending. I really love these. It's so apt, thoughtful and perfect. (e.g The only person who can imprison you is no one but yourself."
- The extra story for one of the characters which gives us further insights and details of her past.
- Great art
- The OST are rather nice

Cons:
- It is tedious to go through everything again to unlock all the endings (Use the guide that Zeiva provided on their website if it gets too tedious and hard.)

It is still worth it to unlock all the endings and the true end!"
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Interesting character study and original premise, somewhat hampered by the developers trying to put in as many endings as possible to pad out the game time. While having to replay the game to collect more pieces and figure out the mystery is not a bad idea, it'll make it a lot harder to look past the somewhat clunky interface, the illusion of interactivity and dreary music while retaining an interest in the story if you go through the same bits up to 9 times. At the beginning I was genuinely intrigued, by the end it was a tedious chore and I wanted it over with.I still enjoyed what I got in the end but it was a hard road getting there.\n\nStill, it's unique and thought-provoking enough to at least give it a shot, though waiting for a sale is recommended; one playthough takes an hour even while exploring all text options.

reviewText:
TL;DNR The game's worth a buy on -75% discount or more.

It has a great and emotionally touching story but suffers highly repetitive gameplay and underdeveloped alternative routes.

The art and music are fine.

The plot is quite clich√© if you‚Äôve read similar works before but I think this is a timeless topic and doesn‚Äôt get old. The author did a great job of portraying it but I felt the emotions of the characters could have been more intensive, especially in some of the alternate endings which, as I mentioned, felt lacking.

There are multiple endings in the game and with little effort one can understand how to get them all but the repetitive nature of the game made getting these endings quite boring and as such made me refer to a guide to get it over more quickly.

Overall, I enjoyed the story and recommend this if it‚Äôs on a big sale. 13 ‚Ç¨ for this is a robbery, sadly.

reviewText: This game was very unlike any visual novels I've played before. It all takes place in one compartment of a train on its way to the afterlife, and there are only a small handful of characters. But the fun of the game is playing it over and over to see all of the endings and find out how it all comes together. It's a sad and memorable story, and at times very creepy.\n\nLike other visual novels, there is a lot of repetition in subsequent playthroughs and I would recommend a walkthrough to figure out how to get the true ending of the game as it's not intuitive.

reviewText:
Pros:
-	Atmosphere. Be it calm or horror, Train of Afterlife knows how to evoke it.
-	Strong soundtrack and minimalistic, effective artwork
-	The story, while not exactly the most complex one, is well told. Strikes a good balance between showing and telling.
-	Everything ties together in the true ending

Cons:
-	Repetition. The story doesn‚Äôt change a lot in the different playthroughs.
-	Certain endings are more effective than others.

I would recommend Train of Afterlife for its atmosphere and storytelling. However, if you value length or dislike rereading/skipping, then it may not be for you. Train of Afterlife probably has more in common with experimental short stories than it does with the typical video game.

reviewText:
Whoa... Didn't realize this game was so expensive! I don't remember exactly how I procured it but I don't remember paying anything close to it. Ah well. It doesn't affect the review much. Perhaps just wait for it to go on sale.

Anyway, moving on the the review. It's a tad confusing and a bit weird but it does all tie up even if some of the plots are loosely knotted up. Basically you have just died and you figured out stuff from your past and who the mysterious boy or girl (you get to choose) named Wing is. Through the power of Tarot and unlocking different ending which give you a passcode, you can progress and learn more of the story.

So I'm gonna go ahead and recommend it but it is an acquired taste. At first, I was like, what the hell is this but it really did grow on me. My only real complaint is I wish there was more to it. It felt a little flat and lackluster. Like it had the potential to be amazing but it just came out ok. But over all? Definitely worth playthrough.

reviewText: This is a lovely, short graphic novel with an eerie quality to it. There are only nine endings, so if you save strategically you should be able to clear the entire game in an evening. A fair warning - for artistic reasons, the author does not have any form of a skip dialog" feature
date: you have to click through everything each time you replay. The music is nice and atmospheric but gets a little dull over time. Like most visual novels
recommended: its story is the best element and the writing is good - no huge monolouges and enough clues peppered throughout that you can form theories around. There's also some nice imagery relating to tarot
hoursPlayed: and the "true" ending wraps up the game nicely. Definitely worth a few dollars
voteText: so buy when it's on sale."

reviewText:
Decent story but being able to come to all 9 endings is impossible without following a guide, as missing one discussion branch/location completely ruins the ending. And all of these decisions happen in the common route, so I hope you like re-reading the same text again and again.

Furthermore, the game forces you to do at least 4 regular endings before being able to pursue the true route, which ruins the illusion of free choice.

$12.99? No. Indie Game Bundle? Worth a read.

reviewText: This visual novel would have been far better as a kinetic novel.  I was rather enjoying the first half when I got an abrupt bad ending that seemed so arbitrary and out-of-place that I considered abandoning the visual novel right there.  Since I had paid thirteen dollars US for this, I went back and reloaded from my last save point.  As I continued, I started to get the feeling that I was being herded toward a specific path.  I did make it to the final hour and got a mysterious, unsatisfying ending.  I decided that once through was enough.  I went to YouTube to see the true ending."  Thirteen dollars is too much for this visual novel.  The time it would have taken to get the true ending would have been too much.  If it had been a kinetic novel with the "true ending" selling for US $4.99
date: then I would have given thumbs up."

reviewText: Train of Afterlife is unlike any other visual novel, rather than showing us brightly colored character that take all of the attention away from the story the game presents us with with shadows of the characters. The characters being shadows also helps to remind the player that everyone on the train is dead and practically a shadow of themselves due to their lack of memories. None of the characters remember what things were like when they were alive or even their own names. Each character has an attachment to something they can't remember which helps them come up with names for themselves to use on their short train ride to the afterlife. Your choices in the game can give you one of several endings, your choices will build up certain stats that ultimately determine how your character perceives their time on the train. Using the tarot cards in the game helps your character to slowly remember their tragic life and they begin to gain back some of their features. Train of Afterlife is one of the most interactive visual novels on Steam and truly feels like it belongs.
